title: What was your most badass moment in high school? - Quora

response.answer_text: In grade 10 I had formed a tight bond with a couple of other guys. We were fairly renowned for being a group of shit disturbers. Now, nothing really bad, but we were the quintessential class clowns. We were frequently sent to the principal’s office for disrupting the class (i.e. making everyone, including the teachers, break out laughing). And look… I get it. It’s really hard to get through to a bunch of distracted teenagers with me cracking wise about Adam Smith’s economic theories. The Vice Principal was a complete jackass. He HATED us and we would frequently whine to our parents that we were complete innocents *cough*, and that the VP was simply out to get us. Our parents, quite obviously, did not exactly embrace our protestations of innocence… until one fateful day. Okay, it’s 1982 and The Who have announced that they’re “packing it in.” This is their “farewell” tour. I need you to picture my bedroom wall: I have a giant black “Maximum R & B” flag hanging in the corner and the wall is completely covered with photos of Pete, Roger, John and Keith (sorry Kenny). I’m also a huge fan of “The Jam” and pretty much all things Mod. I dress like I fell off the cover of Quadrophenia. It was a big deal to me. My parents, being pretty cool for… you know… “parents” at the time… gave us permission to camp outside of the place that was going to sell “bus packages” to Toronto to see the show. Listen, this was the 80’s. There wasn’t “the internet” and “bus packages” were a thing. Okay, so the next day someone pulls a fire alarm at the school and “Mr. Green” immediately grabs the attendance list, looking for suspects. Like a scene out of a cheesy 50’s film noir, he whips out the attendance list for the day and sees that we’re all absent. “Aha!” So Greeny overplays his hand. He grabs the phone and calls my father, informing him that he has WITNESSES who saw us pulling the fire alarm. I like to imagine that he had his feet up on the desk when he made this call. Had this gamble paid off, he would’ve been done with us for good. Pulling a fire alarm is serious shit. Expulsion worthy. Oh, except that we’re sleeping on wet concrete outside of a storefront in the downtown core. My late father (miss you, Dad) says, “Oh you have witnesses, do you? That’s really interesting because my son is waiting outside of Treble Clef with his best friend so that they can buy tickets to see “The Who.” Green’s face must've turned red (you thought I was going to say green, didn’t you?). But Greeny is an uber-dickhead and when cornered, he decides to double-down. “Well, do you think that’s wise to let them skip school for such a frivolous thing?” Bad move, Greeny. Do NOT tell my father how to parent his kid. God, I wish he had recorded that conversation. My dad launches into him. “You know, he told me that you were out to get him and I didn’t believe him. If you harass my son one more time, I’m going to get a lawyer and I’ll have your job.” OMG, the next day at school was THE GREATEST DAY OF MY LIFE!! Sorry, Jenn… it was even better than our marriage. I know that I told you different, but come on… even you have to give that a second place to this. It was like being handed the golden ticket. I could’ve burned that place to the ground after that and Greeny wouldn’t have been able to do shit. The best part was seeing him in the hallway outside of the cafeteria. He held the door open for us, smiling through clenched teeth… “Good morning, gentlemen.” Like the snot-faced little punks we were, we just laughed as we walked through the door, never acknowledging him. He called us back and tore into us about what poor manners we had, but he was a toothless tiger at that point. Eventually I matured (somewhat) and my visits to the principal’s office dwindled off. He did get revenge on my buddy, though. He took out a boundary map of school districts and determined that Jason’s house was one block outside of our high school’s zone. Jason also dated his daughter so I like to imagine that metaphorically, he was just returning the favour.

I was in 12th grade, a senior. I still had Physical Education. But not *just* P.E.. Oh no… Because I was low-vision, I took corrective P.E.! For those of you who have never HAD CorrP.E., it is the “short bus” class. While other students were playing softball, football, basketball and soccer… WE were doing calisthenics (does anyone remember the “Chicken Fat” record?! THAT one!) or stretching, or balancing things. (This is generally where I start the guitar part of “Alice’s Restaurant”) Yes, balancing things. One class the Instructor had us balance a ping-pong ball on a paddle and walk across the gym with it. If we dropped it, we had to start over. With only one functioning eye, I had no depth perception and my coordination isn’t the greatest. I got the paddle and ball and started off. Oops! Crap! I put the ball back on the paddle and tried again. Halfway across OOPS! Crap! On the THIRD trip I got pissed. I grabbed the ball and smacked it on, denting the side in. I set it on the dented flat side and carried it triumphantly across. That was not the badass moment. Oh no. Our teacher was absolutely beside herself! I had never seen an adult come unglued like that! “You BROKE school property! You will REPLACE that ping-pong ball, or you will NOT get your GRADE!” she screamed in my face. “Do you understand me?!” Say what?!! Replace? A? Freakin’? PING-PONG? Ball?! Her face was scarlet, her sweaty hair was in her eyes and I could see her tonsils as she blessed me out for destruction of the (all rise and place your hands over your hearts) Property of the Los Angeles Unified School District. It was one month to graduation; and she was threatening me with loss of that grade. It was also Friday. I went home over the weekend. I came back on Monday. In sixth period, she saw me approaching and met me outside the locker room, “Where is my Ping-Pong ball?!!” Sorry about this, but yes, she always spoke in italics. I feigned ignorance giving her my best Doublemint-popping smile and a vacuous Valley-Girl 18 year old “Huh?” just to see the veins pop out on her forehead. “Ohhh… I forgot.” “You have TWO WEEKS, young lady and I had BETTER have that Ping Pong ball in MY POSSESSION or YOU are not graduating! Do I make myself CLEAR?!” I resisted the urge to scream back “SIR, YES, SIR!!” as I thought OMG, she’s really going to go through with it! Well, luckily for me, she was then out for two or three days and I managed to stall until Friday. I skipped out FAST and spent the weekend planning. I needed my Mama to drive me. We went into L.A. to a fancy sporting goods store. I stepped up to the counter “Ma’am?” The saleslady turned “Yes, may I help you?” “Yes, Ma’am… I need to buy one of your finest ping-pong balls.” She stared, “Honey… don’t you mean you want to buy a box of our finest … uh… ping-pong balls?” I shook my head “No, Ma’am. I only need one… but it has to be the best.” She was dumbfounded. “I never really rated brands before…” she mused “I could sell you a box of Brand Name Forgotten … they’re the most expensive.” I reiterated my need for just one. She looked helpless. Finally I bought a box of six, and re-donated five of them “You can give these to poor homeless kids who need them for crafts classes at the shelter, They make good frog eyes.” I told her as I opened the box and dragged out one precious ball. They cost a whole dollar twenty! But hang the expense. I was On a Mission From God. Next we drove to Wilshire Blvd and the expensive jewelers’ stores. “You need… what?” the tuxedoed jeweler asked incredulously (mind you the shop we went to was a branch of a VERY famous east coast jewelers and they were frequented by the cream of Hollywood). This was Top Of The Line! “Yes, Sir, I need a jewel box that will fit a ping-pong ball.” He was about to throw me and my long-suffering mother out of the shop, when my mother’s boss walked in. He was a multi-millionaire contract attorney who worked in entertainment law. Boss Esquire looked at my Mama and said “Ah, Hello, Elsie!” The jeweler began to ooze delightfully “Oh! Oh my! Well, we simply MUST find that box for you, my dear! A tennis ball, you say?” It pays to have Employers in High Places. “No, Sir, a ping-pong ball,” and then, thinking to make him feel better I lied “It’s for a film.” He felt better. At home I made my preparations. Then I waited through the week. Either skipping class, ducking out early, saying I’d forgotten, as the Corr. P.E. Teacher got progressively angrier and angrier. Thursday, “You have a FINAL tomorrow! That ping-pong ball had better be on my DESK by end of class or you are NOT getting your grade!” “I’ll have it.” I promised. Friday. We had our final. Yes, P.E. classes have finals. I think we did Chicken Fat twice in a row or something. I don’t remember. If you’ve never heard Chicken Fat… go to You Tube and look it up. But be sure there are no firearms or sharp objects in your home before doing so. Oh, and hide the shoelaces and belts too. End of class. The teacher corners me with all the finesse of a bull elk cornering a Pekingese in heat. “WHERE IS MY PING PONG BALL?!!” “I have it in my locker.” I said. She frog-marched me to my locker, the back of my gym blouse clamped in her sweaty hand. I opened my locker. I got out the Van Cleef and Arpels labelled bag. Inside the bag was a gift wrapped small box in the signature style of V.C.&A. She stared. She ripped off the wrapping and found a velvet jewel-box. She opened it. There, gleaming softly, was the ping pong ball. “Well… You came through..” she said, speaking in regular Times Roman letters. Probably for the first time in her life. She signed my grade card.. I took it gratefully and headed for the door. FAST! I could see her reach into the box and I needed to put distance between myself and her. I didn’t actually SEE her inspect the ping-pong ball… but I do know what was in the box. Nothing harmful. I’m not *that* much of a bitch. You see… I had given her… A bag with Van Cleef & Arpels logo in silver. Gift wrapping and a silk ribbon (in the school colors) A tasteful velvet jewel case with a little cushion inside. And a very expensive (twenty CENTS) ping-pong ball… I heard the shrieks as I ran for the bus. Really… I don’t know WHY she was so upset! I had REPLACED the school’s property! I’d even exactly duplicated the DENT in the underside!
